simplified: Dreams can tell you things about yourself, things you didn’t even know you were thinking about. Lots of people have similar dreams, like flying or falling. Dreams about your teeth falling out, or being naked in public, often have a similar meaning for most people. But to understand what *your* dreams mean, think about what’s happening in your life and how you’re feeling each day. Try to connect your dream to those things.
original: Your dreams might show you all kinds of insights into things that you didn't realise you were thinking about. Common dreams like being able to fly or falling, your teeth falling out or having no clothes on in a public place probably mean something similar in most people. But the key to understanding exactly what they mean to you is to connect them to the events and feelings in your daily life.

simplified: Wild dogs in Moscow are a very interesting example of animals living in a city. There are about 35,000 wild dogs living in the streets of Moscow. Some of these dogs were born in the wild, but others used to have owners who left them. Some dogs live by themselves, and others live in groups called packs. In 2010, scientists studied these dogs and discovered they have adapted very well to living in the city. They have learned it’s safer to walk across the road with people, and some dogs even seem to know what traffic lights mean.
original: One of the most interesting cases of wild animals living in a city are the wild dogs of Moscow. In Moscow, there are approximately 35,000 wild dogs living on the streets. Some of the dogs were born wild, while others are pets that have been abandoned by their owners. Some dogs live alone and others live in packs. In 2010, scientists studied the dogs and found that the dogs have adapted remarkably successfully to urban life. They have learned that it is safer to cross the street with people and some dogs appear to understand traffic lights.

simplified: Wonder is the first book by American writer RJ Palacio. She says she got the idea for the book when she saw a girl with a different face in the street. The book has been very popular in the US and has won prizes. Many schools use it to talk about being kind to others, making friends, and accepting people who are different. They are also making a movie of the book. Many people, including me, are excited to see what RJ Palacio will write next.
original: Wonder is New Yorker RJ Palacio's first novel. On her website, she explains that the idea for the book came to her after seeing a girl with facial deformities on the street one day. Wonder has been a bestseller in the United States and has already won several awards. Many schools are using it as a starting point for discussions about bullying, friendship and what it's like to be different. A film version is being made, and many, including me, are waiting eagerly to see what RJ Palacio writes next.

simplified: Chloe has two pet rats called Zena and Roxy. She knows rats aren’t usual pets, and she’s explained to many people that rats are clean and can be great pets if you care for them well. But she understands why some people don’t like them. She didn’t like rats at first either. Then her friend Martin showed her his pet rats, and she saw they were loving and clever. Last year, Martin’s rat had babies, and Chloe decided she wanted two of them.
original: Chloe has two pet rats, Zena and Roxy. Chloe knows they're not typical pets and she has lost count of the times she's patiently tried to explain to people that rats aren't dirty and they make fantastic pets if you look after them correctly. But she understands why people react badly. She didn't like rats either until her friend Martin showed her his pet rats and she saw how affectionate and intelligent they were. Last year, when one of Martin's rats had babies, Chloe decided she'd like to have two of them.

simplified: Cape Town can be a dangerous place for baboons. Some have been hurt or killed by cars, and others have died after touching electric wires. Baboons are an endangered species, which means there are not many left. To help them and reduce problems between people and baboons, the city has hired people called Baboon Monitors. These monitors chase baboons away from towns and cities, or catch them and let them go in the countryside. This plan has worked a little, but it’s difficult to stop baboons from returning to the city because they find food there easily.
original: Cape Town can be a dangerous place for baboons. Some have been injured or killed in car accidents and others have been electrocuted as they played with electric cables. Baboons are an endangered species and to save them and minimise conflicts between humans and baboons, the city council has employed a team of Baboon Monitors. The monitors' job is to chase baboons out of urban areas or catch them and release them in the countryside. This policy has had some success, though it is proving hard to stop baboons from coming back to the city once they see it as a source of easy food.

simplified:
I work for a big computer company, but the main office is in the USA. So, I work from my home using the internet. This means I don’t spend time travelling to work or talking about nothing with people from work.

I work on different jobs, one after another. I like this because it means I can take time off easily when my children have things at school, like a show, or when I need to go to the doctor. 

But, it also has a bad side. Because I don’t have set work hours, I often work late into the night. Sometimes I even miss dinner to finish something.
original: I work for a global IT company, but because their headquarters is in the States, I do all my work online from home. That means that I don't waste time commuting or making idle chit-chat with colleagues. I work on a project basis, and this flexibility is very valuable to me because it means that I can easily take some time off when my children need me to go to their school performances or if I need to schedule an appointment with the dentist. The downside is that without clear office hours, I tend to work well into the evening, sometimes skipping dinner to finish a task.

simplified: In the 1990s, people continued to paint graffiti, but street art also became very popular around the world. Some artists wanted to talk about important issues, like war, unfairness and treating people differently. They made art to make people think about these things. Other artists just wanted to create beautiful pictures. In South America, many street artists worked in poor neighbourhoods. They used colour and art to make grey walls look nicer and more lively.
original: In the 1990s, graffiti continued but there was also an explosion in street art around the world. Some artists wanted to make political points and produced art that tried to make people think about war, inequality and discrimination. Other street artists were more concerned with producing beautiful, attractive work. In South America, many street artists went to work in poor areas adding colour, life and beauty to grey, city walls.

simplified: Every day, people see adverts for things to buy on social media, in magazines and in shop windows. People in Britain are buying more clothes and shoes than ever before. It is now very easy to buy things online without thinking too much. Big companies sell clothes at very low prices, so people sometimes treat them as things you can throw away after wearing them only a few times.
original: Social media, magazines and shop windows bombard people daily with things to buy, and British consumers are buying more clothes and shoes than ever before. Online shopping means it is easy for customers to buy without thinking, while major brands offer such cheap clothes that they can be treated like disposable items – worn two or three times and then thrown away.

simplified: Sam narrowed his eyes against the sun, looking at the dust the car made as it drove up to the large house. The horses kicked their legs and swatted flies with their tails, not noticing their owner was coming back after ten months. Sam waited. Mr Carter didn’t usually come outside unless he needed to, and Sam was happy about that. The less he saw his boss, the safer his job was. Mr Carter wiped his forehead with a cloth. His shirt was wet with sweat, and the wet patches looked like shapes on a map. His skin was getting red from the sun. Usually, he was pale because he spent all day inside making money while others did the work.
original: Sam squinted against the sun at the distant dust trail raked up by the car on its way up to the Big House. The horses kicked and flicked their tails at flies, not caring about their owner's first visit in ten months. Sam waited. Mr Carter didn't come out here unless he had to, which was just fine by Sam. The more he kept out of his boss's way, the longer he'd have a job. Mr, Carter wiped the sweat from the back of his neck. The damp patches on his shirt drew together like shapes in an atlas. His skin was already turning ruddy in the June sun. Otherwise he had the indoor tan of a man that made money while other people did the work.

simplified:
People living in Berlin, Germany were upset because the city was killing wild pigs with guns, and they thought this was very cruel. Hunters and people who love animals argued about it. 

Because people protested, the city government decided to try a kinder way to deal with the pigs. Now, instead of shooting them, they are building fences to keep the pigs in certain areas. It is also now against the law to give the pigs food. 

It’s not clear if this new plan will work. It might be difficult because the winters are getting warmer, so there are more pigs now than before.
original: Many city residents in Berlin, Germany complained that shooting pigs was unnecessarily cruel and there were heated arguments between hunters and animal lovers. In response to protests, the city council decided to take more peaceful action against pigs. Instead of shooting them, they have put up fences and made it illegal to feed the pigs. Time will tell if this strategy works, though it may be a losing battle as warmer winters mean that pig numbers are greater than in the past.

simplified:
Suzanne Collins, the writer of *The Hunger Games*, got a big idea from old Greek stories. When she was young, she loved the story of Theseus and the Minotaur.

In this story, the city of Athens was controlled by Crete, but the people of Athens fought back. As a punishment, the king of Crete, Minos, made Athens send seven boys and seven girls to Crete each year. These young people were put in a confusing maze called a labyrinth, where a monster called the Minotaur would eat them. 

But a young man named Theseus fought the Minotaur and won. Suzanne Collins thinks of Katniss Everdeen, the main character in *The Hunger Games*, as being like Theseus, but in the future.
original: An important inspiration for the Hunger Games book comes from Suzanne's love of classical Greek mythology. When she was a child, one of her favourite stories was Theseus and the Minotaur. In this story the city of Athens is ruled by Crete, but the Athenians rebel. As a punishment, Minos the king of Crete forces the Athenians to send seven boys and seven girls to Crete every year. The youths are thrown into the labyrinth and eaten by a monster that lives there called the Minotaur. But one of the youths, named Theseus, fights the Minotaur and kills it. Suzanne sees Katniss Everdeen as a futuristic Theseus.

simplified:
Zoos can help people learn about protecting animals and where they live. They can show us why it’s important to care for the natural world. Some zoos give a safe home to animals that were hurt or treated badly in circuses, or pets that people didn’t want anymore. Zoos also do important work finding out about how animals behave and how to make them better when they are sick. 

**(Explanation of 'conservation' - protecting animals and their natural homes)**
original: By bringing people and animals together, zoos have the potential to educate the public about conservation issues and inspire people to protect animals and their habitats. Some zoos provide a safe environment for animals which have been mistreated in circuses, or pets which have been abandoned. Zoos also carry out important research into subjects like animal behaviour and how to treat illnesses.

simplified: A new idea is becoming popular that goes against buying lots of things – it’s called ‘buy nothing’. It started in Canada in the early 1990s and then went to the US. People started it because they didn’t want to spend so much money on sales like Black Friday and Cyber Monday, which happen after Thanksgiving. On Buy Nothing Day, people show their disagreement with shopping and some even cut up their credit cards. All year, Buy Nothing groups help each other by sharing things they already have and fixing things instead of buying new ones.
original: A different trend is springing up in opposition to consumerism – the 'buy nothing' trend. The idea originated in Canada in the early 1990s and then moved to the US, where it became a rejection of the overspending and overconsumption of Black Friday and Cyber Monday during Thanksgiving weekend. On Buy Nothing Day people organise various types of protests and cut up their credit cards. Throughout the year, Buy Nothing groups organise the exchange and repair of items they already own.

simplified: Is graffiti art or is it damage to property? It depends on what you think. But in many countries, writing or painting on things that don’t belong to you – like walls or buses – is seen as damage. Police have stopped many artists who do this, and some have had to pay money as a punishment. City governments often say it costs a lot of money to clean graffiti off buildings, buses and trains.
original: Is graffiti art or vandalism? This depends on your point of view, but in many countries, writing or painting on public or private property is considered vandalism. Many street artists have been stopped by the police and some have had to pay fines. Many city councils complain about the high cost of cleaning graffiti off buildings, buses and trains.

simplified:
People who work with art are starting to see graffiti and street art as real art. More and more, they think it has value. Big shows of street art have been held in art spaces in cities like Paris, London, and Los Angeles. In 2008, an American artist called Elura Emerald showed street art in a New York art space. She said street artists are just sharing their ideas, and aren’t causing harm. She believes they should be liked and praised.

**(Explanation of potentially tricky words, not included in the answer, for context):**

* **Graffiti:** Drawings or paintings, often using spray paint, done on walls or other surfaces in public places.
* **Street art:** Art made in public spaces, often using spray paint, but can include other materials and techniques.
* **Galleries:** Places where art is shown and sold.
* **Exhibition:** A public display of art.
original: What does the art world think of graffiti and street art? Recently, there has been a growing recognition of its value as an art form. There have been major exhibitions of street art in galleries in Paris, London and Los Angeles. The American artist Elura Emerald organised a street art exhibition at a New York gallery in 2008. She defended street artists, saying 'artists who paint on the street are merely expressing themselves, not hurting anyone. They should be appreciated and celebrated'.

simplified:
Most people have four to six dreams each night after they are ten years old. That means they can have up to 2,000 dreams every year. By the time someone is 80 years old, they might have had 140,000 dreams!

Even though we forget most of our dreams – usually 95 to 99 out of every 100 – we still remember a few thousand dreams in our life. It’s not surprising that sometimes something in a dream happens later in real life. This is especially true if the dream is about something that often happens to us when we are awake. It can just be a coincidence – meaning it happens by chance.
original: If most people have four to six dreams every night after the age of ten, that's as many as 2,000 dreams per year. So, by the time they reach 80 years old the average person might have had 140,000 dreams. Even if we forget 95–99 per cent of our dreams, that's still a few thousand remembered dreams across a lifetime. It's not too difficult to believe that, by coincidence, a dream event is followed by a real-life event that's similar to it, especially if the subject of the dream is something that happens often in everyday life.

simplified: The Hunger Games is set in the future, after North America was destroyed. Now, the country is called Panem. It has twelve poor areas, called districts, and a rich, powerful city called the Capitol that controls them all. The Capitol has total control over everything. Each district makes something different for the Capitol. The story starts in District 12, which provides coal – a black rock burned for fuel – for the whole country. There used to be a thirteenth district, but they fought against the Capitol a long time ago and were destroyed because of it.
original: The Hunger Games takes place in the future, after the destruction of North America. The country is called Panem and is made up of twelve poor districts governed by the wealthy Capitol. The Capitol holds absolute power over the nation. Each district is responsible for producing different things for the Capitol. District 12, where the story begins, provides all the coal for the country. There used to be a thirteenth district but they rebelled against the Capitol in the past and were destroyed.

simplified: Wild animals sometimes come into towns and cities to find food. In Cape Town, South Africa, baboons – which are like large monkeys – now come into where people live, near the city. They look for food in bins, and eat fruit from gardens and places where fruit trees grow. Some baboons are even bold enough to go *inside* houses and take food from cupboards and fridges! Baboons can be angry and have hurt many pets, so it’s not surprising that people don’t always want them around.
original: Often wild animals come into cities to look for food. In Cape Town, South Africa, baboons have started coming into residential areas on the edge of the city to feed. They open rubbish bins and eat fruit from gardens and orchards. Some brave baboons have even come into people's houses and taken food from kitchen cupboards and fridges! Baboons can be aggressive and have attacked a lot of pet animals, so understandably, many city residents don't welcome their presence.

simplified: Many bridge accidents happen while the bridge is being built. These accidents often happen because of a mistake made by the people who design them, like a wrong calculation. Then the bridge falls down because it’s too heavy, and this can be very dangerous – even deadly – for the workers who are on it.
original: A large number of bridge accidents occur during the construction of the bridge itself. These accidents are often due to an error made by the engineers, such as a miscalculation. The bridge collapses under its own weight, and this can be deadly for the workers on it at the time.

simplified: George Lucas was one of the first film makers to use a special story pattern in his films. This pattern has 17 parts and is called ‘the hero’s journey’. Usually, the main character starts by living a normal life. But then, something happens that makes them go on an adventure and their life changes. In the beginning of Star Wars, Luke lives a normal life with his aunt and uncle, fixing robots. When he finds a message for Obi-Wan Kenobi inside the robot R2D2, this is the start of his adventure. It’s what makes him begin his journey.
original: George Lucas was one of the early film directors to directly base his story on the 17 stages of the hero's journey. Typically the hero starts the story living an ordinary life, but something happens that calls them to an adventure that changes everything. At the beginning of Star Wars, Luke lives an ordinary life with his aunt and uncle, repairing robots. When he finds Princess Leia's message to Obi-Wan Kenobi inside the robot R2D2, it is 'the call to adventure' that starts the hero on his journey.

simplified:
One idea to protect Earth from a big space rock heading towards us is to use a nuclear bomb to destroy it. It sounds like something from a movie – like the film *Armageddon* from 1998 – but NASA actually suggested this in a real plan called HAMMER. 

The plan is to fire big rockets, weighing eight tons, at the space rock. The idea is to gently push it away from Earth. If the space rock gets too close, the rockets would use nuclear bombs to break it apart.

*(A **space rock** is another name for an asteroid or a potentially hazardous asteroid – PHA – which is a large rock in space that could hit Earth.)*
original: Another suggested defence against a PHA on course to hit Earth is to blow it up using a nuclear weapon. It may sound like a plot from a film, and it was the subject of the 1998 film Armageddon, but the Hypervelocity Asteroid Mitigation Mission for Emergency Response (HAMMER) is a genuine NASA proposal. The eight-ton rockets would be fired at an approaching asteroid with the hope of bumping it off course. If the asteroid was too close to Earth for this plan to work, the rockets would carry nuclear bombs to blow it up instead.

simplified:
Campbell says that a hero usually doesn’t want to start an adventure at first. But then someone older and wiser – a mentor – helps them. They then decide to go into a new and different place where the adventure will happen. This is like crossing a line to get to a new world. 

Next, the hero has to pass tests, fight bad guys, and meet people who will help them. This gets them ready for their biggest challenge. For example, in Star Wars, Obi-Wan is Luke’s mentor. Han Solo and the robots R2D2 and C3PO are his friends. And Darth Vader is the enemy, inside the Death Star – that’s the special world in this story.
original: According to Campbell, the hero at first refuses the call to adventure, but a mentor appears who helps them and they decide to 'cross the threshold' and travel into the 'special world' where the adventure happens. The next stage consists of passing tests, fighting enemies and meeting friends as the hero prepares to face their biggest challenge. For Luke the mentor is, of course, Obi-Wan, the friends are Han Solo and the robots R2D2 and C3PO and the enemy is Darth Vader inside the special world of the Death Star.

simplified: Things we don’t use much might not seem valuable, but they can be helpful for other people. Because of the internet, people online have found a way to make money by sharing things they don’t use often. Websites and social media groups now make it easy to buy and sell used items directly between people. This is called the “sharing economy”. It means people are sharing and selling things to each other, instead of just buying new things.
original: Underutilised items may seem useless to some, but could be an asset to others. With the advent of the internet, online communities have figured out a way to generate profit from the sharing of those underused assets. Using websites and social media groups that facilitate the buying and selling of second-hand goods, it is now easier than ever for peer-to-peer sharing activities to take place. And this is known as the sharing economy.

simplified:
Between the 1700s and 1800s, people started to have two main ideas about dreams. One idea was that dreams show things we don’t fully know about ourselves – feelings and thoughts we hide even from ourselves. A doctor named Freud thought that by understanding our dreams, we could understand these hidden feelings and why they cause problems. 

But another idea was different. It said dreams are just what happens when your brain sorts out memories and things that happened during the day. It’s like your brain is busy tidying up! When you wake up, you try to make a story from the strange pictures and feelings you had while dreaming.
original: Around the 18th and 19th centuries two main ideas about dreams became popular. One was the idea that the things we see in our dreams represent things hidden from our conscious mind. Freud believed that if we understand what dreams are telling us, we can understand our hidden feelings and the problems they cause. However, the other theory was the opposite. It said that dreams are just a collection of random activity in the brain while it's organising memories and events from the day. When we wake up, we try to make sense of these random images and feelings and put them into some sort of story.

simplified: I work for myself – I’m a freelancer. This is good because I can choose what jobs I do and how I spend my day. At first, I worked at home, but it was difficult to focus. There were too many things to distract me, like housework, wanting another drink, or my family needing me. So I tried working at a café, but the internet connection wasn’t very good and I drank too much coffee. Finally, I rented a desk in a shared office with five other people who also work for themselves. I liked getting ready for work and being able to concentrate in an office.
original: I'm a freelancer and work for myself. This is great because I am in control of what I do and how I spend my time. At first, I was working from home, but I found it really hard to concentrate. There were just too many distractions around: housework that needed doing, another cup of tea, my family members wanting my attention for various things. So I started to go to a nearby café to work, but the Wi-Fi connection wasn't ideal and I found myself drinking too much coffee. In the end, I decided to rent a desk in a co-working space with five other freelancers like myself. I liked getting dressed to go to work in the morning and being able to focus in an office environment.

simplified:
NASA wants to find asteroids that could be dangerous to Earth. To do this, they need money to build a special telescope for space called NEOCam. This telescope would be 0.5 metres wide and use infrared light – a type of light we can’t see – to find asteroids. 

If NASA gets the money, they think they can find most of these asteroids in about ten years. But finding them is only the first step. Scientists, called the planetary defence team, also need to figure out how to stop the really dangerous asteroids – these are called PHAs – from hitting Earth.
original: Whether NASA can find the remaining middle-sized NEOs depends on getting the money to build NEOCam, a 0.5-metre space telescope which would use infrared light to locate asteroids. If it did get the money, it could probably achieve its goal in ten years. Once logged, the planetary defence team would still need to work out how to defend the planet against being hit by the truly worrying asteroids – the PHAs.

simplified:
More and more people are choosing not to buy things, and now this idea is becoming popular with people who are famous on social media. These people usually show things like clothes and makeup and tell people to buy them. But now, some YouTubers are telling their followers not to buy *anything* for a whole year!

Two friends in Canada tried to only buy food for a year. First, for three months, they stopped buying things like TVs, clothes, and furniture for their home. Then, they stopped paying for services – things like getting haircuts, eating at restaurants, or putting gas in their cars. After one year, they saved $55,000!
original: The 'buy nothing' trend has now reached influencers on social media who usually share posts of clothing and make-up that they recommend for people to buy. Some YouTube stars now encourage their viewers not to buy anything at all for periods as long as a year. Two friends in Canada spent a year working towards buying only food. For the first three months they learned how to live without buying electrical goods, clothes or things for the house. For the next stage, they gave up services, for example haircuts, eating out at restaurants or buying petrol for their cars. In one year, they'd saved $55,000.

simplified:
Pi thinks religion is very important. His family follows Hinduism, but he wants to learn about other religions too. He becomes friends with a Christian priest and a Muslim baker.

Surprisingly, Pi says he wants to follow Hinduism, Islam and Christianity all at the same time. When his family and teachers ask him to choose only one, he says no. He says he just wants to love God. 

After that, his family and teachers let him decide for himself what he believes about religion.
original: Religion is important to Pi. Though his family is Hindu, he is curious about other religions and he makes friends with a Christian priest and a Muslim baker. To everyone's surprise, Pi declares himself to be simultaneously Hindu, Muslim and Christian. When his family and teachers ask him to choose just one religion, Pi refuses, saying 'I just want to love God'. From that moment, his family and teachers decide to let him make his own mind up about religion.

simplified:
Some people believe that writing down your dreams might help you have more control when you dream. These special dreams are called lucid dreams. When you’re having a lucid dream, you know you are dreaming, and you can even change what happens in the dream! 

For example, if you’re having a scary dream, you could make it feel safer. Or, you could decide what happens next, just like a director of a movie. Instead of just trying to understand what your dreams mean, you can start making them happen. But it’s still good to have some dreams where your mind can show you what you’re thinking and feeling without you controlling them!
original: Some people think writing your dreams down can open your mind to lucid dreaming. Lucid dreams are dreams where you're not only aware you're dreaming but you can make decisions to affect the events of your dreams. So, maybe you can turn a nightmare into a safe-feeling dream, or you can direct the plot of your dream like a film director. Then, instead of just working out the meaning of your dreams, you'll be creating them, though you might want to continue having some dreams that allow your subconscious to tell you what's on your mind!

simplified:
Many people don’t know they are part of the problem with clothes we throw away, even if they give their old clothes to charity. But charity shops can’t sell all the clothes people give them. ‘Fast fashion’ means clothes become old-fashioned very quickly, and are often not made well, so they can’t be used again. People don’t want to buy these clothes when they’ve been used before. Lots of clothes end up being thrown in the bin, and a lot that charities can’t sell are sent to other countries. This causes problems for those countries’ economies and the environment. 

**Fast fashion:** Clothes that are made and sold quickly and cheaply, following the latest trends.
original: People might not realise they are part of the disposable clothing problem because they donate their unwanted clothes to charities. But charity shops can't sell all those unwanted clothes. 'Fast fashion' goes out of fashion as quickly as it came in and is often too poor quality to recycle; people don't want to buy it second-hand. Huge quantities end up being thrown away, and a lot of clothes that charities can't sell are sent abroad, causing even more economic and environmental problems.

simplified: Some people who love adventures don’t stop after just one trip – they keep looking for new challenges! Meagan McGrath, from Canada, is one of these people. She has climbed the tallest mountain on every continent (all seven big areas of land on Earth). She also cycled across all of Canada and ran a very long race in the Sahara Desert when it was very hot – 45ºC! But maybe her most amazing adventure was a ski trip to the South Pole. On the first day, she fell into a big ice hole called a glacier and someone had to help her get out. Most people would have stopped there, but Meagan wanted to continue. Forty days later, she arrived at the South Pole. She pulled all her things – a tent and food – on a sledge behind her, even though it was very cold and there were ice storms.
original: Not content with one amazing trip, some of today's adventurers go from challenge to challenge. Meagan McGrath from Canada has climbed the highest mountain on each continent, ridden a bike across Canada and run a long-distance race in the Sahara Desert in 45ºC heat. But perhaps her most remarkable journey was a skiing trip to the South Pole. On the first day, she fell into a glacier and had to be rescued. Many of us would have given up at that point, but Meagan decided to carry on. She reached the South Pole forty days later, having pulled a sledge with a tent and all her food behind her through freezing conditions and ice storms.

simplified: Blek le Rat began by painting rats on walls in Paris. Now, he tries to make people think about problems in society. He paints pictures of people with no homes in big cities to make people think about homelessness.
original: Blek le Rat started out painting rats on the walls of his home city, Paris. Nowadays, he tries to make people think about different social issues and problems. He paints pictures of homeless people in big cities to encourage residents to think about the problem of homelessness.

simplified:
In some towns, local governments have tried to help artists paint without causing trouble. They do this by letting artists paint in special areas. Taiwan is one of these places – they have areas called ‘graffiti zones’ where artists can paint on walls freely. In São Paulo, Brazil, the city government has even allowed artists to paint on some subway trains. 

*(‘Graffiti’ is art made by writing or painting on walls or other surfaces. ‘Zones’ are specific areas.)*
original: In some areas, councils have tried to encourage artists not to paint graffiti randomly on walls by allowing them to work in designated areas. Taiwan is one such place and there are 'graffiti zones' where artists are free to paint and write on walls. In São Paulo in Brazil, the city council has even allowed some graffiti artists to paint on the city's subway trains.

simplified:
Faith47 is from Cape Town, which is a city in South Africa. She makes large, bright paintings of people and animals, and she loves to paint in different places. You can find her art on streets, in old, empty buildings, and even on cars that people don’t use anymore. 

She likes that most street art doesn’t stay for long. Rain or people who clean the city will often remove it. She thinks this is like life – things change all the time, and everything has an end and a new start. 

**(Street art is art that is made in public places, like on walls.)**
original: Faith47 is from Cape Town in South Africa. She paints big, colourful pictures of people and animals and likes to explore different locations. Her work is found on pavements, in empty factories and on abandoned cars. She likes the fact that most street art is temporary and will soon be removed by weather or cleaners from the city council. For her, this reflects how life is full of change with its cycle of endings and new beginnings.

simplified:
Gabriela used to work in a place where people thought it was very important to respect bosses and people in charge. Everyone knew their role, and leaders made most of the decisions – people didn’t usually question them.

But her new team in Sweden is different. They are used to working with their bosses as equals, sharing ideas and making decisions together. Here, leaders help people learn and grow, and they *want* people to share their opinions, even if they disagree. 

**(Power distance is about how much people respect authority. A 'high power distance' means people accept that some have more power, while a 'low power distance' means people see everyone as more equal.)**
original: In her previous work environment, Gabriela was used to a high power distance culture where power and authority are respected and everyone has their rightful place. In such a culture, leaders make the big decisions and are not often challenged. Her Swedish team, however, were used to working in a low power distance culture where subordinates often work together with their bosses to find solutions and make decisions. Here, leaders act as coaches or mentors who encourage independent thought and expect to be challenged.

simplified: Gabriela noticed that her team and she had different ideas about work and how things should be done. So, she talked to them openly about how they felt about her as their leader. The team were happy she asked. They told her they weren’t used to being told exactly what to do. They liked being able to make their own decisions and be creative. When Gabriela told them exactly what she wanted, they felt she didn’t think they could do a good job on their own. They also realised Gabriela felt upset when they questioned her ideas or suggested changes. They explained that this was just how they had always worked.
original: When Gabriela became aware of the cultural differences between her and her team, she took the initiative to have an open conversation with them about their feelings about her leadership. Pleased to be asked for their thoughts, Gabriela's team openly expressed that they were not used to being told what to do. They enjoyed having more room for initiative and creative freedom. When she told her team exactly what she needed them to do, they felt that she didn't trust them to do their job well. They realised that Gabriela was taking it personally when they tried to challenge or make changes to her decisions, and were able to explain that it was how they'd always worked.

simplified: Os Gêmeos are twin brothers from Brazil. They are both the same and look alike. They paint pictures on buildings, sometimes small ones and sometimes very big and colourful pictures of people. Their pictures are often so large that they need big machines, called cranes, to help them paint. These machines lift them up high! In 2007, they painted all the walls of a castle in Scotland.
original: Os Gêmeos are identical twin brothers from São Paulo. They paint everything from tags to huge, colourful pictures of people on the sides of buildings. Their work is often so big that they need cranes to help them work. In 2007, they covered the whole of a castle in Scotland with paint.

simplified: For a long time, people have painted and written on walls. Long ago, people in Africa and Europe painted animals and people in caves. We’ve also found writing on walls in old cities like those in Greece, Italy, Syria and Iraq. In the Roman city of Pompeii, people wrote messages in Latin on walls – about religion, politics, love, and even magic!
original: People have been painting and writing on walls throughout history. In prehistoric times, people in Africa and Europe used to paint pictures of animals and people in caves. Graffiti has been found on buildings at ancient sites in Greece, Italy, Syria and Iraq. In the Roman town of Pompeii, archaeologists have found numerous examples of graffiti written in Latin. These include religious, political and romantic messages, and even some magic spells!

simplified:
Have you ever wanted to climb a very tall mountain like Mount Everest, or walk to the South Pole? Lots of people have these dreams! Every year, many people try to climb the world’s tallest mountains or walk across big areas of land.

In the past, explorers used maps and compasses to find their way. But today, people who go on adventures use new technology like GPS – a tool that shows you where you are – and satellite phones to talk to people. 

Many adventurers love nature and want to help protect it. They travel to tell people about problems with the environment. Others want to help people who need it, and collect money for good causes.
original: Have you ever dreamt of climbing Mount Everest or walking to the South Pole? If so, you're not alone. Every year, thousands of people try to climb the world's highest mountains or walk across continents. Unlike the explorers of the past who used maps and compasses, today's adventurers travel with modern technology like GPS and satellite phones. Many adventurers are nature lovers who use their travels to help raise awareness about a range of environmental issues, while others are keen to help people in need and raise money for charities.

simplified:
There’s a test called DART – that stands for Double Asteroid Redirection Test. Scientists plan to test DART on a small moon that goes around a bigger rock in space called Didymos. This small moon, called ‘Didymoon’, is 150 metres across. Didymos is much bigger, about 800 metres across. They hope that when DART hits Didymoon, it will move it a little bit. Then, telescopes on Earth will be able to see the change in where it is. 

*(An asteroid is a rocky object that goes around the sun. A moon is something that goes around a planet or asteroid.)*
original: The first is DART – the Double Asteroid Redirection Test. Plans are scheduled to test DART on the moon of an asteroid called Didymos. 'Didymoon' is 150 metres wide, orbiting its 800-metre mother, and hopefully the impact of DART will knock it out of its orbit enough for Earth-based telescopes to pick up.

simplified:
The main girl in this story is Katniss Everdeen. She is sixteen years old and her father died in an accident while working in the mines. Now she needs to get food for her mum and sister. She’s good at hunting in the forest near her home, which is in a place called District 12. She uses a bow and arrow really well, with help from her friend Gale.

When her little sister, Prim, is picked to take part in a dangerous event, Katniss steps forward to go instead of her. A boy from District 12, called Peeta, is chosen to go with her. Katniss and Peeta then start to have a confusing relationship. 

**(Note: ‘tribute’ means someone who is chosen to take part in this event.)**
original: The heroine of the story, a sixteen year old girl called Katniss Everdeen, has lost her father in a mining accident and has to provide food for her family. She hunts in the woods around District 12 with her friend Gale and becomes very skilful with a bow and arrow. When her younger sister, Prim, is chosen as one of the tributes, Katniss volunteers to go instead. The other tribute from District 12 is a boy named Peeta and Katniss soon finds herself in a complicated relationship with him.

simplified: If you write about your dreams, you will start to remember more about them. Think about the people and places in your dream – they can help you understand what it means. If you write down your dreams for a week, you will be surprised how much you remember! Then, you can start to think about how your dreams are connected to things that happen and how you feel when you are awake.
original: Writing about your dreams will mean you start to remember more details about the dream, so think about the people and place where the dream happened as they might add to the meaning too. Over the period of a week you'll be surprised how much you've written down. Now you can start connecting your dreams to the events and feelings in your daily life.

simplified: In the past, many bridges were made of wood. Wood burns easily, so these bridges often caught fire. This was especially true for old train bridges. The trains had steel wheels on steel tracks, and this could create sparks. Sometimes, these sparks would set the wooden bridge on fire and it would burn down completely.
original: Historically, more bridges were made of wood and were much more susceptible to fire. This was particularly true of old-fashioned train bridges, where the spark created by the steel wheels and steel tracks could sometimes cause a bridge to catch fire and burn to the ground.

simplified: We can’t know what will happen with street art, but we can see some things starting to happen now. Most street artists are young and paint where they live. But more and more artists are now travelling to different countries to create their art. They are also using the internet to connect with each other and show their work. Plus, people who work with art are starting to see street art as real art. We don’t know what the future holds, but street art will definitely continue!
original: It is impossible to know how street art will develop in the future but certain trends are emerging. While most street artists are young people who paint in their city or neighbourhood, more and more street artists are travelling and working around the globe. Other artists are using the internet to talk to each other and share photos of their work. Also, the art world is giving more recognition to street art as a legitimate art form. Although we don't know what will happen to street art in the future, we can be sure that it is here to stay!

simplified: Suzanne Collines has always felt sad when she watches news about wars. When she was young, her father was a pilot for the American Air Force and he fought in the Vietnam War. Her mother wanted to protect her, so she didn’t talk about the war. But Suzanne still saw news about it on TV and knew her father was there. This was very scary for her.
original: Suzanne Collines has always found news programmes of wars upsetting. When she was a child, her father was a pilot in the US Air Force and he fought in Vietnam. Her mother tried to protect her by not telling her what was happening in the war, but she still saw news programmes about the war and knew that her dad was there. It was a very frightening experience for her.

simplified:
PwC asked over 40,000 people – including those born between 1983 and 1993 (called “millennials”) – about their jobs. They wanted to know what people think about how they work together, how they talk at work, how much they earn, how they can improve their careers, and how well they can balance work and their personal lives.

Deloitte also did a survey. They asked over 10,000 millennials what they think are the biggest problems and best chances in today’s working world.
original: In a global survey conducted by PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC), more than 40,000 millennial (born between 1983 and 1993) and non-millennial responses were collected on the topics of workplace culture, communication and working styles, pay structure, career development, work–life balance, etc. In a separate global survey conducted by Deloitte, more than 10,000 millennials participated in a study about their perceptions of the threats and opportunities in the complex world of work.

simplified:
Erik Weihenmayer is from the United States and loves adventures! He has cycled across the deserts in Morocco, travelled down the Grand Canyon in a kayak, and even climbed Mount Everest. What’s amazing is that Erik couldn’t see after he was 13 years old – he is blind. He also helps people with disabilities to be active and enjoy life. He takes groups of young, blind people on climbing trips. 

*(Kayaks are like small boats you move with paddles.)*
*(An expedition is a long, planned journey, often for exploration.)*
original: Erik Weihenmayer from the United States is a multi-adventurer. He's ridden a bike through the deserts of Morocco, kayaked through the Grand Canyon and climbed Everest. Amazingly, Erik has been blind since the age of 13. Apart from his travels, he tries to encourage people with disabilities to live active lives and takes groups of young blind people on climbing expeditions.

simplified:
It’s now easier for people to earn a little extra money online. For example, parents who are busy might not have had time to sell things at a local market before. But now, with websites and apps for selling, they can easily sell things like baby clothes their children have grown out of. They can also sell pushchairs and other baby things they bought, to get some money back. 

**(Explanation of terms, not included in the simplification as requested, but for clarity: 'car boot sale' is a type of market where people sell things from the back of their cars; 'pushchair' is a stroller.)**
original: Democratised online platforms are providing a chance for people to make a quick buck or two. To give an example, busy parents previously might not have bothered with setting up a stall at the local market or car boot sale to sell their children's old equipment, but with online marketplaces, parents are now able to sell on those hardly worn baby clothes that their children have outgrown and the expensive pushchairs and baby equipment they have invested in, so as to put some cash back into their pockets.

simplified: Pi and Richard Parker are on a lifeboat for 227 days. It’s a very hard time – they are very hungry, get sick, and become extremely tired. They experience strong, dangerous storms and very hot sun. But they manage to stay alive. Sometimes Pi feels better because of his beliefs, but often he feels very alone and sad. After a long time, they finally see land – the coast of Mexico – and things start to change. I won’t tell you what happens next, you’ll have to read the book to find out what happens to Pi and Richard Parker when they reach land.
original: Pi and Richard Parker spend 227 days in the lifeboat. They live through hunger, illness and exhaustion. They endure violent storms and the burning heat of the Pacific sun, but somehow they survive. At times, Pi finds comfort in his three religions, but at other times he is overcome with loneliness and despair. Finally, the Mexican coast appears on the horizon and everything changes. It would be a shame to give away the ending, so you will have to read the book yourself to find out what happens to Pi and Richard Parker once land is in sight.

simplified: Chloe got home from school and made herself a coffee. She took it upstairs to her bedroom. She had homework, but she didn’t need to do it right away. She wanted to enjoy the peaceful time before her mum and dad came home. Then the house would be noisy with talking, the TV, or her dad listening to his favourite jazz music while he made dinner. She also liked this time because she could play with her pet rats.
original: Chloe arrived home from school, made herself a cup of coffee and took it up to her bedroom. She had some homework to do, but that could wait for later. She wanted to enjoy the quiet hour before her parents arrived home and the house filled up with the evening sounds of chatter, television or her dad listening to his beloved jazz while he cooked dinner. She liked this time of day too because she could play with her pet rats.

simplified: In 2010, NASA – the US space agency – had found and noted 90 out of every 100 big asteroids near Earth. These asteroids are over 1 kilometre wide, which is about the size of a mountain. We call these ‘near-Earth objects’ or NEOs. A NEO is anything that comes within 50 million kilometres of where Earth travels around the sun. NASA thinks there are about 50 more of these asteroids to find. But they say that none of the 887 they already know about are likely to hit Earth and cause serious harm.
original: In 2010, the planetary defence team at NASA had identified and logged 90 per cent of the asteroids near Earth measuring 1km wide. These 'near-Earth objects', or NEOs, are the size of mountains and include anything within 50 million kilometres of Earth's orbit. With an estimated 50 left to log, NASA says none of the 887 it knows about are a significant danger to the planet.

simplified:
Auggie decided to go to school, and then he had to face his first day. Like all children starting a new school, he was very worried. But because of how he looked, it was a really difficult experience. No one wanted to sit with him, and he noticed other children looking at him or talking about him when he wasn’t looking. Luckily, he became friends with Jack, a boy in his class, and Summer, a girl he talked to during lunch. 

It wasn’t just the first day that was hard, though. Auggie soon found out that his classmates didn’t want to touch him because they were afraid of getting sick – they called it ‘the plague’, meaning a serious illness. As the school year went on, Auggie had many good and bad times. Then, something shocking and upsetting happened at a school trip, and it changed everything.
original: Having decided to go to school, Auggie then has to face his first day. Like every child starting at a new school, he is really anxious. But because of the way he looks, it's an agonising experience. Nobody wants to sit next to him and he notices other kids staring at him or talking about him behind their hands. Fortunately, he makes friends with Jack, a boy in his class, and Summer, a girl he chats with at lunch. But it's not just the first day that's hard. Auggie soon learns that his classmates don't want to touch him for fear of catching 'the plague'. As he goes through the school year, Auggie goes through many intense ups and downs till finally an unexpected and traumatic event at a school camp changes things completely.

simplified: The two men looked towards the north of the land. It went on and on, as far as they could see. Even the fences were hard to see from where they were. A teenage boy might be unhappy and want to cause trouble, but he couldn’t walk away and escape. Sam looked at the largest horse, stamping its big feet on the ground. He wondered if the boy could ride. A good rider could get into a lot of problems out here, far from anyone. But maybe someone who didn’t know anything about horses, and wanted to escape his dad, would be in even more trouble.
original: The two men looked towards the northern end of the property. It stretched as far as the eye could see. Even the fences were barely visible from where they stood. However bored and rebellious a teenage boy might get, it wasn't possible to escape on foot. Sam looked at the biggest of the horses, kicking at the ground with its heavy hooves. Could the boy ride? he wondered. There was a whole load of trouble a good rider could get into out here, miles away from anyone. But maybe there was even more trouble for someone who knew nothing about horses and wanted to get away from his father.

simplified: More than 4,000 people have climbed to the top of Mount Everest. These people were between thirteen and eighty years old. Climbing very high mountains, with cold weather and strong storms, is still very dangerous. But the best climbers in the world now want to try even harder things. Gerlinde Kaltenbrunner is from Austria and she loved climbing mountains when she was a young girl. After school, she worked as a nurse, but she continued to climb mountains when she had free time.
original: Over 4,000 climbers, aged from thirteen to eighty have been to the top of Everest. Though climbing high mountains in freezing conditions and violent storms is still extremely dangerous, the world's best climbers now look for new challenges. Gerlinde Kaltenbrunner from Austria fell in love with mountain climbing as a teenager. When she left school, she worked as a nurse, but kept climbing in her free time.

simplified: Gerlinde climbed Everest and then wanted to climb all fourteen of the world’s highest mountains – mountains over 8,000 metres. She makes it harder for herself by not using oxygen. This is dangerous because there is not much oxygen at the top of high mountains, and this can make you ill. Gerlinde uses her success to help a charity that supports children in Nepal who don’t have much money or a family.
original: Having climbed Everest, Gerlinde decided to climb all fourteen of the world's 8,000 metre peaks. To increase the challenge, Gerlinde climbs without using oxygen tanks. This is risky as low oxygen levels at the top of high mountains can affect brain and body functioning. Gerlinde uses her fame as a climber to support a charity for poor children and orphans in Nepal.

simplified: If you look at the things you have bought, you’ll probably see you don’t use everything. For example, maybe you have a warm coat, but you live in a hot country. Or perhaps you stopped using an old phone when you got a new one. Maybe you only drive your car on weekends. Or a spare room in your house might be full of things you don’t need anymore.
original: If we look around us at the things we have purchased at some point in our lives, we would no doubt notice that not everything we own is being put to good use: the thick woollen coat which we thought looked trendy despite the fact that we live in a tropical country, the smartphone that got put away when we bought ourselves the newest model, the car that only gets used at the weekends, or even the guest room in our house that somehow got turned into a storeroom.

simplified:
For a long time, and in many different countries, people have believed dreams can tell the future. They used to think dreams were messages from gods, helping us understand things or learn secrets. Even now, lots of people remember dreaming about something – a place, a person, or something that would happen – and then it actually *did* happen later. 

**(Prophecy means telling the future. Insight means a clear understanding of something.)**
original: Throughout history and across cultures, dreams have been associated with prophecy. People thought dreams were messages from the gods, sent to give us knowledge or insight. Even today, many people can recall a time they dreamed about an event, place or person and then, later, the dream came true in real life.

simplified: Building bridges is often a very big and costly job. Bridges are really important because they help cars, trucks and trains get across rivers, deep valleys, or other roads. Because of this, building bridges is a key part of civil engineering – that’s the work of designing and building things like roads and buildings. People look at bridges very carefully, especially if one breaks or falls down.
original: Some of the biggest and most expensive transportation projects in the world have involved building bridges. Bridges are crucial links that carry cars, trucks and trains across bodies of water, mountain gorges or other roads. As a result, they are one of the most important aspects of civil engineering and are subject to intense scrutiny, especially when they collapse.

simplified: Gabriela was unhappy with her team for several weeks. She sent an email to her boss in Sweden to explain the problems. Her boss only asked if she thought her team was doing a good job, and what could help her work better with them. Gabriela thought her boss was not clear and didn’t help her solve the problems well enough. She didn’t feel he was managing things properly.
original: After weeks of frustration, Gabriela emailed her Swedish manager about the issues she was facing with her team. Her manager simply asked her if she felt her team was still performing, and what she thought would help her better collaborate with her team members. Gabriela found her manager vague and didn't feel as if he was managing the situation satisfactorily.

simplified: Dogs that live in groups have learned that people are more likely to give food to small, cute dogs. So, these dogs are often sent to ask for food for all the other dogs in the group. Some dogs are very clever and have even learned how to use the city’s underground trains to travel around their area! Scientists don’t know how the dogs know when to get off the train. One idea is that they use their good sense of smell and recognise smells of places they like. Another idea is that they learn to recognise the names of train stops when they hear them announced. Either way, people who travel on the trains are now used to seeing dogs, and the dogs usually go unnoticed by people in the city.
original: Dogs that live in packs have learnt that humans are more likely to give food to smaller, cuter dogs so those dogs are sent to beg for food for the whole pack. Some dogs have even learnt to use the city's metro system to get from one part of their territory to another! Scientists are not sure how the dogs know when to get off the train. One idea is that they use their excellent sense of smell and have learnt to recognise the scents of their favourite destinations. Another possibility is that they have learnt to recognise the names of stations they hear in announcements. Either way, metro passengers have now got so used to the sight of dogs on the trains that they travel largely unnoticed by locals.

simplified:
Ed Stafford is from the UK and he was the first person to walk all the way along the Amazon River. He began his walk at a small river high in the Andes Mountains in Peru. Two years and four months later, he finished at the end of the river in Brazil. He walked 6,000 kilometres!

The Amazon rainforest is a dangerous place with poisonous snakes, crocodiles, and jaguars. Ed was in danger all the time. Luckily, he was okay, even though he got bitten by lots of mosquitoes and ants – thousands of them! 

**(Explanation of ‘rainforest’ if needed: A rainforest is a forest with a lot of rain.)**
original: Ed Stafford from the UK is the first person to walk the length of the Amazon River. He started by a small stream in the Andes mountains of Peru and arrived at the river's mouth in Brazil, two years and four months later, having walked 6,000 kilometres. The Amazon rainforest is home to poisonous snakes, crocodiles and jaguars, so Ed was in constant danger. Luckily, he survived with nothing worse than a few thousand mosquito and ant bites.

simplified:
In the UK, people spend over £1,000 on clothes each year. This is about 4% of how much money they earn. This doesn’t seem like a lot, but it shows some problems for people and the planet.

Firstly, many people are buying clothes using credit cards. People in the UK owe about £670 each to credit card companies. That’s almost two-thirds of the money they spend on clothes each year. Also, people are spending money they don’t have to buy things they don’t really need. 

The UK throws away 300,000 tonnes of clothes every year. Most of these clothes end up in landfill – special places where rubbish is buried.
original: In Britain, the average person spends more than £1,000 on new clothes a year, which is around four per cent of their income. That might not sound like much, but that figure hides two far more worrying trends for society and for the environment. First, a lot of that consumer spending is via credit cards. British people currently owe approximately £670 per adult to credit card companies. That's 66 per cent of the average wardrobe budget. Also, not only are people spending money they don't have, they're using it to buy things they don't need. Britain throws away 300,000 tons of clothing a year, most of which goes into landfill sites.

simplified: It would have been impossible for Ed to complete his walk without help from technology. He used a radio to ask people living in the rainforest for food and if he could walk through their area. Lots of them came to meet him and showed him the way through the hardest parts of the forest. While he was walking, Ed wrote a blog – like an online diary – to share what happened each day. He also used the attention from newspapers and TV to talk about how the rainforest was being destroyed, and to collect money for charities that help the environment and children in Brazil and Peru.
original: Ed's walk would have been impossible without technology. He used a radio to ask the people of the rainforest for food and permission to cross their land. Many of them came to meet him and helped guide him through the most difficult terrain. As he walked Ed wrote a blog, recording his day-to-day experiences. He used the media interest in his trip to protest about the destruction of the rainforest and raise money for environmental and children's charities in Brazil and Peru.

simplified:
Companies have realised they can make good money from the “sharing economy” and are trying to benefit from things people aren’t fully using. A new way for companies to work is becoming very popular. They create websites or apps that connect customers with people who can offer something they need. 

For example, Airbnb helps people earn money by renting out spare rooms or houses to travellers. Airbnb is like a go-between – it connects people who have a place to rent with people who need a place to stay. Uber is another example. It lets people use their own cars to give rides to others and earn money when they have time.

**(Sharing economy explained: This means people are sharing things they own – like a room, a car – with others, usually for money.)**
original: Businesses have caught on to the profitability of the sharing economy and are seeking to gain from making use of those underutilised resources. A business model that has rapidly risen in popularity sees companies providing an online platform that puts customers in contact with those who can provide a particular product or service. Companies like Airbnb act as a middleman for people to cash in on their unused rooms and houses and let them out as lucrative accommodation. Another example is Uber, which encourages people to use their own personal cars as taxis to make some extra cash in their free time.

simplified:
Today, zoos are very important for helping to save animals that are in danger. They do this by helping animals have babies, especially rare ones.

Sometimes, it’s hard for these rare animals to find partners and have babies in the wild. Also, people who hunt illegally (called **poachers**), losing their homes (**habitat**), and other animals that hunt them (**predators**) can all cause problems. 

A good zoo keeps these animals safe so they can live and have families. 

When there are very few of a type of animal left, they can become too similar to each other. This isn’t healthy. So, zoos help by breeding animals and then releasing them back into the wild. This helps make sure there’s a wider mix of genes, which is better for the animals’ future.
original: One of the most important modern functions of zoos is supporting international breeding programmes, particularly for endangered species. In the wild, some of the rarest species have difficulty in finding mates and breeding, and they might also be threatened by poachers, loss of their habitat and predators. A good zoo will enable these species to live and breed in a secure environment. In addition, as numbers of some wild species drop, there is an increased danger of populations becoming too genetically similar. Breeding programmes provide a safeguard: zoo-bred animals can be released into the wild to increase genetic diversity.

simplified:
These accidents almost never happen, but boats and trains can both cause a bridge to fall down – and for different reasons.

Trains are dangerous because of how fast they are going when they hit a bridge. Boats are dangerous because they are very heavy. Even if a boat isn’t going fast, its weight can make a bridge fall. 

The best way to stop these accidents is to be prepared. We can use new technology to find problems with bridges before they happen. Making sure workers are safe and designing bridges better can also help to prevent these awful accidents.

**(Explanation of 'structural weakness' - included within the simplification as 'problems with bridges')**
original: Both of these kinds of accidents are extremely rare, but boats and trains can cause a bridge to collapse for different reasons. With trains, it's the velocity of the impact that can bring a bridge down. With boats, it's the very large mass they have that can bring about the collapse, even if they are moving very slowly when it occurs. The best way to avoid bridge failures is to plan for them. Modern technologies that can detect structural weakness, safer working environments and better designs can all help to reduce these terrible accidents.

simplified: At first, Pi is very scared of the animals and jumps into the sea. Then he remembers there are sharks in the water, and understands he has to get back into the boat. One by one, the animals in the boat kill and eat each other, until only Pi and the tiger remain. Luckily for Pi, the tiger – who he calls Richard Parker – feels sick and doesn’t want to eat him right away.
original: At first, Pi is terrified of the animals and jumps into the ocean. Then he remembers that there are hungry sharks in the water around him and realises his only option is to climb back into the lifeboat. One by one, the animals in the lifeboat kill and eat each other, till only Pi and the tiger are left. Fortunately for Pi, the tiger, who he names Richard Parker, is seasick and has no immediate interest in eating him.

simplified: When Pi is 16 years old, a new government is chosen that his parents don’t like. They are worried about what will happen, so they decide to close their zoo and move to Canada. They sell some of the animals to other zoos in America and Canada. The family travels to Canada on a ship, with the animals too. During the journey, there’s a very bad storm and the ship goes down into the sea. Sadly, Pi’s family and the people working on the ship all die, but Pi finds himself on a small boat with a hyena (a wild animal like a dog), a zebra (a black and white striped animal), an orang-utan (a type of large ape) and a very big tiger.
original: When Pi is 16, a new government is elected that his parents don't support. Worried about the future, Pi's parents decide to close the zoo and emigrate to Canada. Some of the animals are sold to zoos in North America and the family travel by ship to Canada taking the animals with them. On the way, there is a terrible storm and the ship sinks. Tragically, Pi's family and the ship's sailors all drown, but Pi finds himself in a lifeboat with a hyena, zebra, orang-utan and an enormous tiger.

simplified: The Hunger Games is a very popular book for young people, written by Suzanne Collins from America. It came out in 2008 and has been translated into 26 languages. Millions of people have bought it! It was the first young readers’ book to sell over a million copies online. Now it’s also a famous film, and it’s very successful too. It made 152.5 million dollars in its first weekend in North America!
original: The Hunger Games is a hugely successful book for teenagers and young adults by the American author Suzanne Collins. Since it was published in 2008 it has been translated into 26 different languages and has sold millions of copies around the world. It is also the first book for young readers to sell more than a million electronic copies. The Hunger Games is now a major Hollywood film and is just as successful. It made 152.5 million dollars in its opening weekend in North America alone!

simplified: Dreams might happen because our brain sorts out what we think about during the day. But in dreams, these thoughts often appear as symbols – things that represent other things. When we are awake, we usually think using words, like when we talk to ourselves in our head. But when we sleep, the part of the brain that helps us with language doesn’t work as much. Instead, the part of the brain that controls our feelings becomes more active.
original: Maybe dreams are the result of our mind organising the thoughts we have during the day, but they appear in dreams with symbolic meaning. When we're awake, our thoughts mostly appear in our minds as words, like conversations we have with ourselves. But when we're asleep, the part of our brain that controls language becomes less active while the part that controls emotions becomes more active.

simplified: Having good relationships with people is very important for happiness. A study showed that most happy people have close friends and family, and they see them often. It’s also important to have at least one person you can really talk to about your feelings – sharing your thoughts and feelings is called ‘self-disclosure’. Just one close friend is enough, along with other friends too. It’s not enough to just have friends to do activities with, or to talk about things like music or sports. It’s important to have a deeper connection with someone. Some people need to learn how to listen well to others to make their relationships stronger.
original: Having good relationships is a big part of being happy. In one study, most happy people were found to have strong ties to friends and family and they made sure they spent time with them regularly. You also need at least one person who you discuss personal feelings with – called 'self-disclosure'. Just one person for a heart-to-heart is enough, together with a network of other relationships. It's not enough to have lots of friends just to do things with or chat to about music or football. That deeper connection is all-important. Some people need to learn how to listen effectively to others in order to develop stronger relationships.

simplified:
Carol Dweck, a psychologist who studies how people learn, says our brains can change. This means we can get better at things even if we aren’t naturally good at them.

Lots of people praise others for being clever or talented, like saying “You are very good at noticing small things” or “You are a natural at planning parties”. But studies show it’s better to praise *how* someone does something. 

If we praise effort, trying new things, and finding solutions to problems, people are more likely to learn and improve. This helps them develop new skills and get even better at things they already do well.
original: Psychologist and 'growth mindset' proponent Carol Dweck spoke of the plasticity of the brain and our ability to develop skills and talents that we might not have been good at to start with. Many of us tend to focus our praise on the end result and seemingly innate talents, e.g. 'You really have an eye for details' or 'You have a real talent for organising events'. However, research suggests that by focusing on the process of how things are done – praising effort, experimentation and problem-solving strategies – we can encourage the development of new skills and the continued honing of talents.

simplified:
The rover checks the air around it from time to time. In 2014, it found something in the air called methane. Methane is a simple chemical found in natural gas. 

Methane doesn’t last very long – only a few hundred years. This means something on Mars is making more of it. NASA says Mars releases a lot of methane, thousands of tons at a time. The amount of methane changes with the seasons, going up and down, almost like the planet is breathing.
original: The rover analyses the air around it periodically, and in 2014 it found the air contained another of the most basic organic molecules and a key ingredient of natural gas: methane. One of the characteristics of methane is that it only survives a few hundred years. This means that something, somewhere on Mars, is replenishing the supply. According to NASA, Mars emits thousands of tons of methane at a time. The level of methane rises and falls at seasonal intervals in the year, almost as if the planet is breathing it.

simplified:
When Carol Dweck, a psychologist from Stanford University, started her work, she gave some ten-year-old children puzzles that were a little difficult. Some children were happy about the challenge. They said they enjoyed trying hard and believed they could get better at things. Dr. Dweck called this a ‘growth mindset’ – meaning they think about what they can learn and do in the future. 

But other children got upset. They thought the puzzles were testing how smart they were, and they felt like they had failed. Dr. Dweck called this a ‘fixed mindset’ – meaning they believed they couldn’t really improve. Some of these children said they might try to copy others’ answers. Others tried to feel better by finding someone who did even worse than them.

*(‘Psychologist’ means someone who studies how people think and feel. ‘Mindset’ is a way of thinking about your abilities and qualities.)*
original: Early in her career, the psychologist Carol Dweck of Stanford University gave a group of ten-year-olds problems that were slightly too hard for them. One group reacted positively, said they loved challenge and understood that their abilities could be developed. She says they had a 'growth mindset' and are focused on what they can achieve in the future. But another group of children felt that their intelligence was being judged and they had failed. They had a 'fixed mindset' and were unable to imagine improving. Some of these children said they might cheat in the future; others looked for someone who had done worse than them to boost their self-esteem.

simplified: Horror movies often use places where no one lives anymore. This could be an old, empty hospital, a frightening empty house, or a town with no people in it. There’s just something about places that are lonely and empty. What was it like when people *did* live there? Why did they go away? Maybe it’s also because they are so quiet – and quiet can be really scary. Also, it’s easier to believe you can’t get a phone signal in these places, which is good for a scary movie!
original: Horror films love uninhabited places. This could be an abandoned hospital, a scary empty house or a ghost town. There's something about lonely, empty places. What was it like when people lived there? Why did they leave? Maybe it's also that they are so quiet, which can be very scary too. Of course, abandoned places are also handy for horror film directors in that it's more believable that you will have no phone coverage there either.

simplified: In scary movies, the basement is always a frightening place. Something bad is usually hidden there, or a dangerous person keeps their things there. Basements are dark and often wet. You go down to them using a small set of stairs. Basements always feel creepy, even if nothing is actually there.
original: No matter what kind of house it is, the basement is a scary place in horror films. That's usually where something is hiding or where the evil psychopath has hidden their tools. Basements are always dark and often damp. You can only reach them by a narrow staircase. And basements are always creepy, even when there isn't anything down there.

simplified:
Gary Collins was a policeman who was not working when he saw the London riots on television. He quickly recognised some people he knew and stopped his holiday to help the police. He spent six months looking at videos from security cameras and found 190 people who were involved, often just by recognising their faces. His help was very important to the investigation. Even though police looked at 200,000 hours of video, a computer program could only find one person. 

**(Explanation of terms, not included in the answer as per instructions):**

* **Riots:** A violent disturbance of the peace by a crowd of people.
* **CCTV:** Short for Closed-Circuit Television – security cameras.
* **Footage:** Video recordings.
* **Facial recognition software:** A computer program that can identify people by looking at their faces.
* **Off-duty:** Not working.
